intro: Chorizema costatum, commonly known as the waxy beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy, waxy leaves and showy yellow flowers that bloom in the summer. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and disturbed areas. Due to its hardy nature, it is considered an invasive species in some regions.
